He was about five months in my employ occasionally—he should bring money to me immediately he received it—I sent him for this between eight and nine o'clock in the evening—he absconded, and I saw nothing more of him till the 16th—I had trusted him to collect small sums before, and had no reason to doubt his honesty before—he was quite sober when he went—he had about half-a-mile to go—it was on the 9th of November—I do not know whether there were any crowds about at that time—I gave him 9s. a week—I cannot say whether he might have lost it—he was generally steady and sober.
NOT GUILTY .

267.
WILLIAM BROWN and
JAMES SMITH were indicted for
a conspiracy.

RICHARD CLARKE . I am a coach-maker in Stanhope-place, Southwark-bridge-road. A few days before the 2nd of September Brown came to my shop—he asked if I had a headed phaeton to let on hire—I said, "Yes," and showed him one—he did not approve of it—I showed him another one, for which we agreed—he wished to hire it for three months—he told me he was a ship and insurance broker—that his offices were at No. 18, East India-chambers, and he resided at Blackheath—I saw him again on the 2nd of September, when he brought a memorandum of agree-ment with him—this is it—he inquired if the phaeton was ready for him—I told him it was, and he produced this memorandum, which he signed in my presence, and he brought another, which I signed—a man from a livery-stable brought a horse, which, was harnessed to the phaeton and he drove away—I saw him again repeatedly—in about a week after, he said he would buy the phaeton for a friend of his who liked it, if I would take 30l. instead of 35l.—I said I could not take that, and then he inquired for a new britska—he looked at one and made me an offer for it—I think I told him 110l. as the price—he offered 90l. which I refused—I never agreed to take 90l.—he came a great many times after that about the britska—on some of these occasions Smith was with him—Brown came almost every day; perhaps five or six times—I agreed to sell the britska for 95l., a German shutter and some other things were to be added to it—Isaw both the prisoners several times—Smith generally came with Brown in a phaeton which was hired of Mr. Gray—on—the 16th of September Brown came and asked if his clerk had been there—I did not know who he meant—I said, "No"—he said he should have been there half-an-hour ago, with a check for 100l. to pay me for the britska—while we were talking Smith came in with a check for 550l., and gave it into Brown's hand—he said "What do you bring me this check for? this is 550l.; you should have brought me a check for 100l."—Smith said that was what Mr. Marsden had given him—Brown scolded Smith for not bringing him the cheek he ordered—it was dated forward—Brown said to Smith, "This is making it appear as if I wanted to do Mr. Clarke out of the britska"—he said to me," This is a very vexatious thing that he should have brought this—I can't pay you for it now, and I have made an arrangement to use this carriage—I wanted to use it for two or three days to go into the country—this will entirely put me out of my arrangement"—he told me that Marsden was a friend of his, in the corn-trade—that he had lent him 550l. to make purchases in corn, and as corn was getting up, he thought it was a good speculation, and the money was to be paid when he demanded it—that he had seen Marsden and told him he had pur-chased a new britska and wanted a check for 100l. to pay for it; "and now," says he, "I suppose he thinks I want the money, and he has written me out this check, which has a few days to run, thinking it would be of service to him"—he then proposed to give me a bill, and he sent Smith for a stamp—it rained fast and Smith asked if I would lend him an umbrella—I went to get one, but had not one at home—after that Smith went out and was some time gone, and Brown and I had some conversation—I said "A gentle-man's word is as good as his bill; I don't require a bill if you will pay me the money before Saturday night"—he said, "The money shall be sure to

be paid before Saturday night"—Smith then returned, and the two prisoners rode away in the britska—a horse and harness was brought to take it—in a day or two, Smith came and asked me for something, as it was usual to allow the servant something—I said, "You are not his groom or servant, you are his clerk"—he said no, he was not, but his servant had asked him to call for him, as he was unable to come from Blackheath to receive it—I said, as Mr. Brown was to pay on Saturday, after I received the money I would give the servant something—Brown came about the 18th or 19th of September, about buying the phaeton—he agreed to buy it for 30l.—after that he brought the phaeton he had hired of Mr. Gray, and asked what I would paint it for—he said it belonged to a friend of his—I afterwards found it belonged to Mr. Gray—he said he and his friend would call the next Monday—he did not leave it, and I never saw him again—on the Saturday on which I was to have been paid for the britska. I received a note from Brown—I afterwards found my phaeton at the police-office, and the britska at the Red Lion, Maidenhead.

(The note being ready stated that Brown had been disappointed and post
poned payment for a week.)

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did Smith at all appear till after Brown took the phaeton? A. Not in the hiring—I will not swear as to the first time Smith came—they came at different times—Smith was present when the britska went away—he was not in the shop when Brown and I agreed for 95l.—after that, Smith generally came and stood in the street, or at the door—I and Brown were in the shop together—Smith came sometimes alone to see how the alterations were going on—I had written out a bill of parcels and given it to Brown—I think it was on the 17th that Smith came and wanted some money, and I think Brown came the day after, and bought the phaeton at the sum we agreed, and said he should pay for the britska on the 21st, and the phaeton on the 28th—the cheque that Smith brought was to be paid on the 21st, and on the 21st Smith came to me with the note—I believe it was previous to that, that he had called and asked me for something for the servant, but I will not swear it.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. Q. Was Brown a perfect stranger to you when he called, a few days previous to the 2nd of September? A. He was—he said he had not a card in his pocket, but he gave me his address, which I wrote down," No. 13, East India-chambers, Leadenhall-street"—I did not make any inquiries about him—I went there, and saw the name on the side of the passage, "Mr. William Brown," and I thought that had the appearance of respectability—I made inquiries afterwards, and found he never lived at Blackheath, but I did not inquire between his first and second call—the britska was to be paid for by ready money, before it went out of the shop—I made no other inquiry before I let him have the phaeton on hire, or sold him the britska. thinking to have the money for the britska I thought it was no use to inquire—Brown's papers have been taken from him by the policeman, and I believe the bill of parcels was amongst them—I sold the phaeton for 30l. or 35l., I cannot swear which.

JOHN CLARK . I keep the Red Lion Inn at Maidenhead. On the 24th of September, the two prisoners came to my house in a new britska. they stopped at my house that night—they went away next morning, and came back about twelve o'clock—they asked me if I had any one I could send to fetch a phaeton, which was coming by the railway—I sent a person and went myself, to see that it was all right—the phaeton came—Brown

said to me (while Smith was by his side) that the phaeton was for sale, that it was a cheap bargain—I said, had it been the beginning of the Spring I would have bought it—he said he had had it new ringed and painted, and I should have it for 30l.—I declined to buy it—I have since seen that phaeton, in presence of Mr. Clarke—they left my house in the phaeton, and went over the bridge towards Hounslow—they told me to be sure and take care of the britska.

JURY to RICHARD CLARKE. Q. You say that Smith left your place before the britska was taken away? A. Yes—to fetch a stamp for Mr. Brown—he was aware the britska was not paid for—I was not in the counting-house when Smith returned.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Did you see Smith after he came back? A. Yes—I saw no stamp.

OSCAR HARD . I am a potatoe-salesman, in Upper-marsh, Lambeth. I know the prisoner Smith, by the name of Knight—he is a printer by trade—he was apprenticed to Beale, in Charlotte-terrace, and they opened a printing-office in Gibson-street—I had not seen Smith for a year or two—on the 26th of September last I drove to the Bell-inn, Hounslow—I was going to take refreshment—I saw Knight and Brown—I went into the parlour, and Knight followed me—I said, "Have you come from London?"—he said, "No, from Maidenhead"—Isaid, Have you walked?"—he said, "I came in a phaeton"—I went into the yard, and saw a phaeton, and was examining it when Knight came out and said, "That is my phaeton"—I said, "I know a gentleman who wants to buy one"—he said, "I will sell it to you for 30l.—I said, "Where can I see you in town,"—he said, "I don't live in town, but I shall sleep in town to-night; I will meet you any where to-morrow morning"—I had my horse put to, and was going off, when Knight came up with—Brown, and said, "If you like you shall have it for 25l."—I said, "It wants a little doing to it"—Brown said, "It only wants a little harness-maker's work" Smith said he had a new one, and did not want two.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You were not born a potatoe-sales-roan? A. No—I have been so a great many years—I have been in the brokering line—I was in the police about twelve months—I left because I did not like it, seven or eight years ago—I resigned.

GEORGE WELLER . I am in the employ of Mr. Gray, a livery-stable keeper. Brown came to our yard at the latter end of August and several times previous to the 3rd of September, and on that day he hired a horse and phaeton—he referred me to Mr. Had win, an attorney—I went to Salis-bury-square, where Mr. Hadwin lives—I saw him—he said he had known—Brown some years, he was a ship and insurance broker, and had resided at Liverpool, and was quite competent to pay any debts he might contract—on that I let him have the horse and phaeton—he drove away on the 3rd of September—I saw Smith and Brown riding together in the phaeton at Charing Cross on the 12th—Brown told me he lived at Blackheath—I went there and could find no such person—he was to have them three months, and was to pay twelve guineas at the end of the first month—I asked for money first, but he said he did not do business in that way, he paid at the end of a month, but I received nothing—I found the horse and phaeton at Chilcott's livery-stables in the Kent-road on the 27th—while I was there I saw Smith coming out, driving Mr. Gray's horse and Clarke's
phaeton—he gave me his name as Knight—I pursued him, and he was taken.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Is this the first time you have been examined? A. Yes—Brown had the conversation with me.
Cross-examined by MR. JONES. Q. Did you go yourself to Blackheath? A. Yes, ten days after I let the phaeton.

ROBERT TELFORD . I am a hair-dresser, and live in London-road, Southwark. In August last Brown took two rooms on my second floor at 10s. a week—a wife and two children were with him—they all lodged there—they were there seven weeks at the time Brown was taken up—he was away for two or three days at the beginning of the week—they had no ser-vant—I do not think any one came to visit them—Brown generally went out in the morning at nine or ten o'clock and returned in the evening—he appeared a regular man.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Smith was not in the habit of coming there? A. No.

JOHN HEARD . I am a porter at the East India Chambers. Brown had been several times about an office, and on the 31st of August he concluded an agreement for it—he took two rooms, letter C—he was to pay thirty guineas a year—the desk and things in the room were mine, and he agreed to buy them for 5l.—he took possession on the 31st—I did not see him after that—he did not pay me the 5l.—there was no rent due—an old man named Twisdale was acting as clerk to him—he came there repeatedly—there were plenty of things came from tradesmen and the parties took them away again, because I represented what I thought he was—I do not know a man of the name of Hadwin.

JOHN REYNOLDS . I am shopman to Mr. Richards, a hatter in the Strand. On the 21st of September Brown drove up to the door in a double-bodied chaise—Smith was sitting inside—Brown came in, and said, "Is Mr. Richards in?"—I said "No"—he said, "I want a hat," and he tried on one—he then said, "My servant wants a hat"—Smith came in and tried one on, and got one to fit him—Brown then said he wanted one with a gold band, not so good a one as that—I said we had very good ones at 13s. 6d.—at last he got one that fitted him—Brown said to Smith, "Is that one that fits you?"—he said "Yes"—I showed Brown the pat-tern-book for the band, and he chose one at 12s. 6d.—he said, "I will take these two, and you can send that before five o'clock"—he had thrown down his card before that, as residing at the East India Chambers—he said, I must send it before five o'clock, as he left town at five, for his house at Blackheath—Brown took his hat away on his head—I put Smith's in a box. thinking he was the servant—I had some doubt, while I was putting it into the box, whether I should let them go, but Brown took up a leather-case and asked me the price of it—I said 10s.—I thought I would let them have the two hats at a venture—I sent the other hat and the gold band at five o'clock, and they were not there.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. Q. I suppose the hat Brown tried on was such as you expected a gentleman like him to wear? A. Yes—Smith was not in livery—Brown said, "My servant wants a hat," and he beckoned Smith in—the hat that Smith had was not so good as Mr. Brown's, but it was better than the one that was to have the gold band—he did not call Smith his servant in his presence.
JOHN GALLIERS . I am foreman to Messrs. Bailey's, ironmongers in

Holborn. On the 10th of September the two prisoners came there in a carriage—Smith remained in the carriage—Brown came in and selected some knives and forks, two candle-lamps, and a study lamp—the goods came to 6l. 12s.—he asked if I could send them down to his chambers, and gave me his card," 13, East India Chambers"—I said I could not, as we had no one in the way—he said he wanted them very particularly, as he had a dinner party that day at Hampstead, and if I would get them ready his servant should call for them in the course of an hour—he then left—I was to get the knives and forks ready, and the other things were to be got ready in a day or two—in about an hour Smith came again in the same carriage—I delivered the knives and forks to him, and I asked him where his master, or where Mr. Brown, resided at Hampstead—he said he did not recollect exactly the address, but it was near the Beau de Ville—I then asked how long his master had resided there—he said, ever since he had been with him.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where did this conversation take place? A. In my employer's shop—I made some inquiry, and could not hear that there was such place as the Beau de Ville—Ihave not been there to inquire.

GEORGE DAVIS . I am a sadler, and live in the Borough. I saw both the prisoners at my shop in September—Brown came in, while Smith sat in the phaeton—Brown asked me the price of chaise and carriage harness, but more particularly of carriage harness—I agreed to make him a set of carriage harness to order for 21l.—the chaise harness was not determined about—he said he resided at Blackheath, and had Cham-bers at the East India Chambers—the harness was to be made and sent by that day fortnight—he said the horse he had at Blackheath was of the same size as the one at the door, and one collar would fit either—after we had agreed about the harness he said he wanted a saddle and bridle immediately, to ride the next day, being Sunday—we looked one out—he said his servant, meaning Smith, would call for it in half an hour—I think he was to pay five guineas for that—Smith called, and took away the saddle and bridle—I have never been paid for either.

— BLACKWELL. I live in Oxford-street, and am a sadler. Brown came to me in a phaeton, and agreed to purchase a carriage harness, for which he was to pay twenty-five guineas—if was lo be made for him, and paid for before delivery—he gave me a card with "East India Chambers" on it, and said he lived at Blackheath—a saddle and bridle were to be sent by the carrier to Blackheath, as he said he wanted to ride on the Sunday—Smith was sitting in the phaeton as a servant—Brown went to the carriage again, and said he was going to dine at Connaught-square, and his servant should call for the saddle and bridle as he returned—I said it should be ready, and asked for a reference—he looked at my book, which was on the table, and said he knew several of my customers, and said they were friends of his—Smith came about half ah hour alter, and took away the saddle and bridle—I asked him where his master resided at Blackheath—he said, "Very near the Hare and Billet public-house"—I said, I never was there but once, and did he know Admiral Oliver's—he said, "Yes," it was a very little way from there—he took away the saddle and bridle, and I heard no more of them till they were at Union-hall.
WALL. I am a sadler, and live in Piccadilly. Brown came

to me about the 20th of September, he said he wanted to look at some phaeton harness—he ordered some to be finished by the following Monday, and then he spoke about some saddlery and horse clothing—he chose a saddle and ordered it to be finished—he gave me one of his cards at the East India Chambers, and said, his coachman should come and have the horses measured—as he was going away he turned and said, "Could you oblige me with the saddle in half-an-hour?"—I said, "Yes," and Smith came and had the saddle—I said to him, "I don't know who I am indebted to for your master's custom"—he said he did not know, and said, Did he order a harness of me? I said, "Yes," where did he live, he said his country house was at Richmond.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Are you certain that Smith was the person who came as the servant? A. Yes, he was at the door holding the horse.

WILLIAM THOMAS (police-sergeant P 17.) I took Smith into custody in Lambeth-road—he was driving a horse and phaeton—I afterwards ap-prehended Brown coming out of a house, No. 106, London-road—I found upon him different bills of parcels, and on Smith a pocket-book, and two bills of exchange, drawn by Twisdale.

BROWN—
GUILTY .

SMITH—
GUILTY .
Confined Two Years.

268.
WILLIAM CLARK was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of November, 1 pair of breeches, value 8s., the goods of
William Moores.

WILLIAM MOORES . I am ostler at the Bald-faced Stag public-house, at Putney. On the 12th of November I lost a pair of cotton-cord breeches out of the settle in the tap-room, where I had left them when I went to bed—these are them.

JAMES HERRICK . I am landlord of this house. The prisoner went outlast on the night in question—he had something under his smock-frock—there was a traveller sitting with him, who slept at my house—the pri-soner left at a quarter to eleven o'clock—no one left after ten o'clock but him.

ABRAHAM HOWELL . I am bailiff to Colonel Wemys, of Kingston. On the 13th of November I went to an out-house belonging to my master, and found this pair of breeches—the prisoner slept there that night.

GUILTY . Aged 39.—
Confined Three Months.

269.
CHARLOTTE SHEARER was indicted
for feloniously receiving, on the 25th of October, 3 yards of sackcloth, value 2s., the goods of
John Murray; well knowing the same to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

ALEXANDER PATTERSON . I live with my uncle, John Murray, of Church-street, Minories, a hemp and sackcloth-manufacturer. This sack-cloth is his—we have not sold it—I cannot say whether we have lost it—we employ from thirty to forty hands—it might have been removed from the premises.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did I understand you that it had not been sold? A. This piece had not—here is three yards and a foot of sacking—our sacks are made chiefly by women—they are given out to be made—I suppose this is a piece given out to make—I believe the pri-soner is married.
NOT GUILTY .

270.
MARY ANN TOMLINSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of November, 1 half-crown, the monies of
John Mantin, her master.

CHARLOTTE MANTIN . I am the wife of John Mantin, a pork-butcher, in Great Suffolk-street, Borough. The prisoner was my servant for four-teen days—on the 7th of November I missed a half-crown from a drawer in my bed-room—there was one more half-crown, a sovereign, and some shillings there—on the Saturday after, I went to the prisoner's mother, and stated the case—her mother came home with me, and asked her if she had a pocket—she said yes—her mother took up her clothes, and said she had some money in it—there were two shillings found in it—the prisoner then said she found it in the bed-room—I said, "You must have taken the half-crown from the drawer"—she said she had not—her mother went, and fetched the policeman, and at last she said she took it from the drawer.
JEMIMA TOMLINSON . I am the mother of the prisoner. My husband is a wheelwright—what has been stated is true.

GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Transported for Seven Years.

271.
ELIZABETH M'CALLISTER was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of November, 1 gown, value 4s.; and 1 petticoat, value 2s.; the goods of
Sarah Ann Barr.

SARAH ANN BARR . I live in service at Battersea. On the 19th of November I hung these things up to dry, between eleven and twelve o'clock in the yard—it is fenced round, but the gate was open—I missed them.

THOMAS EMMERSON . I am a policeman. I was on duty in the Wands worth-road on the 19th of November, about six o'clock—I met the prisoner carrying this basket—I asked what was in it—she said, "Some books and some lucifers"—I opened it, and found some books and lucifers, also this gown and petticoat—I took her to the station-house—she said she bought them of a boy on Wimbledon-common.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought them.

GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Three Months.

272.
JOHN COLEMAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Octo-ber, 1 firkin, value 6d.; and 4 gallons of size, value 1s. 3d.; the goods of
Benjamin Young.

GEORGE CARTER . I am in the employ of Benjamin Young, of Spa-road, Bermondsey, a glue and size manufacturer. He employs about one hun-dred hands—the prisoner was one of his carmen—it was his duty every morning to get his cart loaded by one of the foremen—on the morning of the 23rd of October I loaded it—I put in six firkins of double—brown size, and twenty-four firkins of single-brown size—Clements, another carman, was to have a load of white size that morning.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How do you know that? A. I saw it in the order-book, and either Mr. Young or the clerk told me to send it—it is my duty and Mr. Smith's also to see to the loading of the carts—I am quite certain that there were only six firkins of double-brown size put in the prisoner's cart, and he had seven in it—one was white size, which he had brought back the night before.

WILLIAM SMITH . I am a foreman to Mr. Young. On the morning of the 23rd of October, I was standing at the counting-house door—the pri
soner's cart was drawn up—I saw Godfrey, a labourer, loading Clement's cart—I saw him go with a tub of white size on his shoulder, and when he got to Clement's cart the prisoner stopped him and said something to him—Godfrey put the tub on the prisoner's cart, and the prisoner drove away.

Cross-examined. Q. How far were you off? A. Twenty yards—before I was at Mr. Young's I was at a copperplate-printer's in Little Moorfields—before that I was in the police—I left it on my own account—I stopped away for some time—they sent for me back again, and then it was read out that I was discharged for neglect of duty—I went up and resigned on my own account—my neglect of duty was because I did not give notice to leave.

DENNIS GODFREY . I was in the employ of Mr. Young. On the 23rd of October I loaded Clement's cart—I had to pass the prisoner's cart to go to Clement's—I had a firkin of white size on my shoulder—the prisoner told me to put it on his cart, and I did so.

Cross-examined. Q. How long were you in prison about this? A. Only a few days—I told of this the day it happened, before I was taken up—I was not a party to taking it—I was perfectly innocent—it is my duty to load any man's cart when I am ordered by the foreman—I was in the police—I was not discharged—I resigned.

WILLIAM WILKINS (police-sergeant A 11.) I took the prisoner—I was before the Magistrate—I saw the Magistrate sign this examination—(looking at it) read, "The prisoner says, I never saw the firkin of size—I know no-thing of it."
NOT GUILTY .

273.
CATHERINE M'MAHON was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of November, 15 yards of printed cotton, value 10s., the goods of
John Dennis and another; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

JAMES STRUTT . I am assistant in the shop of John Dennis and another, in Tooley-street. On the 9th of November the prisoner came and asked for something, I could not tell what—I asked heragain—she muttered something, and was going out—I went to her and pulled up her cloak, and saw this piece of print, which she had taken from the counter.

JAMES HIGHWOOD . I am a policeman. I received the prisoner into cus
tody.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going into the shop for a skein of silk—my foot kicked against this print—I took it up and was going to the light—this gentleman came and said I had taken it off a pile.
JAMES STRUTT . It was close under her arm when she was going out.
GEORGE SAWYER . I am a policeman. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction, which I got from the Clerk of the Peace office for Surrey—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Transported for Seven Years.

274.
WILLIAM BENTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of November, 4 skins of leather, value 12s., the goods of
Thomas Learmouth and another; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Six Months.

275.
EMMA ELLARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of No
vember, 1 workbox, value 1l.; 2 necklaces, value 15s.; 1 pair of ear-rings, value 15s.; 1 brooch, value 10s.; 1 bonnet, value 5s.; 13 sovereigns, 2 half-sovereigns, 19 shillings, and 1 sixpence; the property of
James Wall, her master, in his dwelling-house; to which she pleaded

GUILTY .—
Transported for Ten Years.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, DECEMBER 16TH, 1839.
